name: Malayan Tapir
description: While adults are black and white, juveniles are brown with longitudinal white stripes and spots, which serve as camouflage in the undergrowth despite their apparent conspicuousness.
food_note: Branches, leaves, herbs, water plants, fruits
image_alt: Malayan Tapir, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 220–250 cm, shoulder height 90–110 cm, weight 250–320 kg
reproduction: The female is pregnant for 390–395 days and gives birth to 1 offspring.
attractions: Tapirs are odd-toed ungulates, despite having four toes on their front feet and three on the back. Their most striking feature is the elongated upper lip and nostrils forming a short trunk, used like an elephant’s for foraging, smelling, and breathing in water.
projects_note: Destruction of their rainforest habitat has reduced their numbers by over 50% in the last 30 years. Today, a maximum of 5,000 Malayan Tapirs survive in the wild.
breeding: The first Malayan Tapir in Prague Zoo was a female, Isolda (nicknamed Šosina), living here from 1967–1990. The current pair, Niko and Indah, occupies a separate exhibit.
